lead_paragraph: A phaseout of hydrofluorocarbons could have a major effect on climate change but would make air-conditioning more expensive just as many Indians are becoming able to afford it.

byline.contributor: Ellen Barry reported from Delhi, and Coral Davenport from Kigali, Rwanda.
byline.original: By ELLEN BARRY and CORAL DAVENPORT

headline.print_headline: Accord May Push Air-Conditioning Out of India’s Reach
headline.main: Emerging Climate Accord Could Push A/C Out of Sweltering India’s Reach

snippet: A phaseout of hydrofluorocarbons could have a major effect on climate change but would make air-conditioning more expensive just as many Indians are becoming able to afford it....
abstract: Accord is being negotiated in Rwanda by more than 170 countries that would ultimately ban use of heat-trapping hydrofluorocarbons across globe; agreement could put even cheapest air-conditioners out of reach of millions in India, where number of high heat-index days continues to climb.
